newsitem.title: INDONESIA: SE Asian Cocoa - Prices firm on active buying.
newsitem.headline: SE Asian Cocoa - Prices firm on active buying.

text.p: Indonesian cocoa prices held steady on Wednesday and sustained active short-covering was expected to keep values firm next week despite steadily rising supply, regional traders said.
In Malaysia, buyers were sidelined on the back of ample supplies although average prices quoted by the Malaysia Cocoa Board showed an increase over last week.
The traders said sentiment in Indonesia was also lifted by gains posted in London and New York overnight on short-covering and light speculative buying, respectively.
"The exporter has been paying very high prices for his beans, and the talk is that the company has large contracts to fill for May," he said.
"The company bought some 250 tonnes on Tuesday alone. I reckon it has several thousand tonnes at hand," he added.
Traders said crop arrival at Ujung Pandang had been increasing steadily as the main crop harvest proceeded unhindered, adding that the peak was likely to come in May.
"Supply is improving and more beans are expected to come over the next two months," he said. "But price increases in London and New York are making some sellers...hold back."
The trader said he was finding it difficult to get beans from his regular suppliers because of the active short-covering and higher prices paid by those seeking to fill contracts.

"I am about to ship out a couple of thousand tonnes," he said. "But getting fresh supply is becoming a problem because sellers are either holding back or selling to buyers who are paying a premium over market prices."
In Malaysia, the market hardly moved over the last week with both traders and consumers saying they had ample stocks of beans and were not pressed to buy.

The Malaysian Cocoa Board quoted Standard Malaysian Cocoa (SMC) Grade 1 A out of Tawau, the country's main growing area in the eastern state of Sabah, at an average of 3,310 ringgit a tonne, up 28 ringgit from last week.
The board quoted the SMC 1B grade out of Tawau at an average of 3,258 ringgit, up 18 ringgit from the previous week.
Traders offered the SMC 1A at 3,260 ringgit a tonne and the SMC IB at 3,333-3,343 ringgit.
"The market's been extremely quiet," said a trader in Singapore who monitors the Malaysian market. "Everyone seems to have enough bean stocks and there's no fundamental news to urge any buying."
-- With contributions from K. Baranee Krishnaan in Kuala Lumpur + 603 230-7509
